conclusion: The problem involves predicting which container (E, F, G, or H) liquid from sources A, B, C, and D will flow into after passing through baffles.

There are several baffles in the image, including a green slanted barrier, a white horizontal baffle, a brown slanted barrier, and a yellow baffle.
The green slanted barrier is positioned to deflect streams A and B to the left.
Stream C straddles the green slanted barrier and bifurcates into two paths.
Stream D encounters the yellow baffle and is deflected to the right.

premise: The green slanted barrier deflects streams A and B to the left.
conclusion: Streams A and B merge and flow together along the left wall.

premise: Stream C bifurcates after straddling the green slanted barrier.
conclusion: One part of stream C flows rightward along the white horizontal baffle, while the other part flows downward.

premise: One part of stream C flows rightward along the white horizontal baffle.
conclusion: This part of stream C encounters the brown slanted barrier and is deflected to the left.

premise: Stream D is deflected to the right by the yellow baffle.
conclusion: Stream D flows along the right wall.

premise: Streams A and B merge and flow along the left wall.
conclusion: The merged stream of A and B flows into container E.

premise: One part of stream C flows downward, and the other part is deflected leftward by the brown slanted barrier.
conclusion: Stream C primarily flows into container F, with some droplets reaching containers E and H.

premise: Stream D flows along the right wall.
conclusion: Stream D flows into container H.

premise: No streams are directed toward container G.
conclusion: Container G does not receive any liquid.
